qas.question: What are vocalizations of the name of God, YHWH?

answers.text: the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit

qas.question: In the time of Atenism, what was God called?
What is the Islamic name for God?
What do members of the Bahá'í Faith call God?
What was the first monotheistic religion?
What is the God of the Hebrew Bible called?
What is the Christian God called?
What are the 2 titular names of God in the Jewish religion?
Where do scholars believe the name Adonai came from?
In the Egyptian era of Atenism, what were YHWH and I am that I am used as?
What are Yaweh and Jehovah used in Atenism as?
In Christianity what is Bramen considered?
In Aten what is the name for the Holy Spirit?
In Sikhism, how many persons are attributed to God?

context: There are many names for God, and different names are attached to different cultural ideas about God's identity and attributes. In the ancient Egyptian era of <a5_0>Atenism<a5_0/>, possibly the earliest recorded monotheistic religion, this deity was called <a2_0>Aten<a2_0/>, premised on being the one "true" Supreme Being and Creator of the Universe. In the Hebrew Bible and Judaism, "He Who Is", "I Am that I Am", and the tetragrammaton <a6_0>YHWH<a6_0/> are used as <b10_0>names of God<b10_0/>, while <a0_0><a7_0>Yahweh and Jehovah<a7_0/><a0_0/> are sometimes used in Christianity as <b11_0>vocalizations of YHWH<b11_0/>. In the Christian doctrine of the Trinity, God, consubstantial in <b14_0>three<b14_0/> persons, is called <a1_0>the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit<a1_0/>. In Judaism, it is common to refer to God by the titular names <a8_0>Elohim or Adonai<a8_0/>, the latter of which is believed by some scholars to descend from the Egyptian <a9_0>Aten<a9_0/>. In Islam, the name <a3_0>Allah<a3_0/>, "Al-El", or "Al-Elah" ("the God") is used, while Muslims also have a multitude of titular names for God. In Hinduism, Brahman is often considered <b12_0>a monistic deity<b12_0/>. Other religions have names for God, for instance, <a4_0>Baha<a4_0/> in the Bahá'í Faith, <b13_0>Waheguru<b13_0/> in Sikhism, and Ahura Mazda in Zoroastrianism.
